===Etymology 2===
First appears in the ''{{w|Engishiki}}'' compilation of laws created in the early 900s, spelled phonetically in kanji as {{lang|ja|阿良良伎}} (''araragi''). Spelled as {{m|ja|蘭}}, ''araragi'' literally means “wild onion” and refers to the wild [[rocambole]], possibly [[hardneck]] [[garlic]], notable for its tall green stalk sticking straight up. Used as a [[euphemism]] for {{lang|ja|塔}}<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref> (''tafu'' at the time), as that word's Buddhist connotations were viewed as [[taboo]] in contexts having to do with the religious center of ''Itsuki no Miya'' ({{l|ja|斎宮}}, also known as ''{{w|Saikū}}'').

# {{abbreviation of|lang=ja|sort=あららぎ|塔舞|tr=Araragimai|nocap=1|dot=:}} the title of a piece of bugaku Japanese court dance
